Posts.Content: Well it's been a while since l have posted here. You may remember Hubby had surgery in October last year. G7 but only 1% off pattern 4. Stage tb3 no lymph nodes tested. Well RP a failure PSA has doubled in 6 months while at the lower level of 0.23 it means a scan is in order followed by further treatment. Basically we need to find out where the tumour is. Funny when all this started they said you have G6 go home forget it you'll die of something else. Lucky hubs was on the ball! Hopefully the salvage treatment will kill it off. Hope everyone else is going ok.
Posts.Title: Another update

Posts.Title: Another update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ron_G Jimbow, if I recall correctly, a few months ago she posted there was EPE and some surgical removal complications possibly due to the biopsies causing previous damage. I don't recall about the lymph nodes. But, yes. It sucks. Wishing our friends from 'Down Under' the best. Thank you Ron Yeah does suck, we have a skype conference with oncologist, GP on Thursday, hoping to get into a trial for OH that will cover the costs of the PET scan but at the same time hoping it helps men in the future who are being treated. The scan only picks up tumours in 30% of men, so guessing if its in the prostate bed it'll be radiation and hormone but there was mention of chemo if it metastasised. Hoping that's not the case.
Posts.Title: Another update

Posts.Content: Thanks guys yes I did post some months back, PSA was 0.1 then 0.07, then up to 0.15 then 0.23. The surgery OH had was difficult as the prostate was obliterated due to biopsies so surgery took much longer. It was staged tb3 because it was out of the prostate 40 - 50% of the tumour Extensive Perineural and Seminal invasion Was 1% off a pattern 4 apparently. I too was surprised they never took some lymph nodes to test. But can't change it now we just have to deal with it. The G6 was a result of a TRUS biopsy that missed the cancer, the template biospy picked up that there was more than first thought and when they removed the prostate far more advanced than they anticipated. AS can be an effective way to monitor PSA but keep on the ball with it. OH's almost doubled quite quickly so we knew something had been missed. Under normal circumstances with slow growing PC it would have been ok.

AgeInfo.Phrase: was out of the prostate 40   50% of the tumour Extensive

Posts.Title: OK all, so I had my first post-op PSA blood draw yesterday

Posts.Content: Hi Michael Yes he did have an MRI it showed nothing. PSA at the time this occurred was 7.8 (2014)Some letters said 7.2 but path says 7.8. In 2010 it was 5.8 but nobody said a thing. In October 2014 he was biopsied and told that he had PC but it was only in 2 cores and about 1 - 2mm. So we went on AS. In April 2015 I believe he had his second follow up blood test which indicated a reading 12.8. Original urologist moved and he was referred to anew urologist who then preformed a template biopsy about mid August this year. This revealed a G7 with a number of positive cores through out the prostate concentrated on the lobes particularly left hand side. It took 3 weeks to get the results then we were told that the cancer was more aggressive and we needed to consider treatment. We chose surgery since he was still fairly young and we thought it was all in the capsule. He was then operated on almost 3 weeks ago and the rest is what I wrote in the first post! I don't have a copy of the current path report but see the specialist in 4 weeks for the results of the first PSA test. Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Webster & Husband! Remain optimistic and hopeful that all PC was removed with the prostate. If in the event of recurrence, Salvage Radiation would be the next step. Several Forum Brothers have gone this route and are doing perfectly well with undetectable PSAs. If comfortable, can you share some additional information that will be helpful to all? Specifically: - Did he ever have an MRI or CT scan of his prostate? - How many months elapsed between the G6 biopsy and the G7 biopsy? - What were his PSA values during this time? - How many weeks between his G7 biopsy and prostate surgery? - If you have a copy of his surgical Pathology report, can you share the "findings?" - Where are you being treated? In our battles with PC, we all experience The Dreaded "Wait" and associated anxiety! - We have the Biopsy and WAIT for the results - Surgery is scheduled and we WAIT for several weeks for the surgery day to arrive - After surgery we WAIT for the Path Report - Post surgery we monitor our PSAs regularly to detect recurrence. We have our blood drawn and then anxiously WAIT for the result. Good luck with your next PSA! May it and all subsequent PSAs remain undetectable! MF
Posts.Title: Update

Posts.Content: Some time ago I posted on this forum re my OH having been diagnosed with Prostate Cancer, at the time it was G6 3+3. So we undertook Active survelliance for a period of time. However his PSA doubling time was only a matter of months which indicated he had something more aggressive happening. After a template biopsy, score was changed to G7. After much thought and prayer OH decided to proceed with a radical prosectomy. During surgery there were some complications so the surgery took twice as long. This was due to the prostate being obliterated with tissue stuck in surround areas. It's suggested this may have occurred after the biopsies. OH is recovering well, however surgeons needed to remove more tissue than anticipated, both nerves removed and more. Upon grading of the prostate we were told the cancer was quite advanced and had escaped the prostate capsule to start on the seminal vesicle but that it was still a G7, nothing about staging but the conversation suggests bordering on a T3. We have been told there is a much higher chance of re occurance in this situation. In four weeks we will have a PSA test to see where levels are. Fingers crossed its a 0 for many years to come!! Anyway many thanks to those on the forum that helped us through this very difficult time, in particular highlander, your help and support was very appreciated
Posts.Title: Update

Posts.Content: Hi Highlander, so as to not hijack the other thread here's an update. I now have the path report, I won't scan in but will list some of its content Cancer is not gone, PSA reading is only 1 though so its not the worst news but not the best. I now have the path report of the prostate after grading. G7 3 + 4 BUT its 1% off being a 4 + 3. Pattern 4 affecting 40 - 50% of tumours. 40% of the prostate volume is cancer. pt3b stage. I won't bore you with any more info but now the plan is to wait 3 months do another PSA and go for a more expensive PET scan (1200 not covered by medicare)before having further treatment. Apparently it could be any where in the body. I guess it could have been worse, my only concern is that the cancer grew so quickly there is a fear this could happen again. I know its not likely but then we were told in the first place it wasn't likely, but tumors went from 2mm to 35 mm (largest in months). Step by step the journey continues, hoping though the remaining cancer can be mopped up and that a cure is possible.
Posts.Title: Update - Highlander

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone will pass on your very valuable advice! And yes I acknowledge I have a terrible lack of knowledge in this area but it all happened so quickly and the GP was more in favor of retesting the PSA but wanted to be thorough so sent him to the specialist. The specialist may be in over kill mode but then again it may be warranted. However I shall do more research and educate ourselves more on this topic so we can make informed decisions. Thank you all again, I shall let you know how we go
Posts.Title: Hi Advice please

Posts.Content: Thank you for that NYC that will be why the Urologist has recommended the biopsy. I don't remember the exact free PSA number but I have a feeling it was something like 0.08 (can't confirm that as I do not have the paper work) Looking online the lower the number the higher the chance of cancer? I will ask questions, thank you for that!
Posts.Title: Hi Advice please

Posts.Content: Thanks all, yes I agree highlander its not the very worst of news just not the best but we are confident he will come through this. Jim I am sorry I forgot to mention I am in Australia so our medicare system is a little different. Here most things are covered but the odd scan is not. This happens to be one of them. I'll save up and we'll just pay, would rather have piece of mind. We have to wait 3 months for the next test anyway to see what the PSA is doing.

Posts.Title: Hi Advice please

Posts.Content: Hi all, Recently OH had his PSA checked which came back as 7.8, up from 2.2 4 years ago. He is only 57. This set in motion some tests, MRI and a TRUS biopsy that is scheduled in the next 90 to 120 days. Public hospital system wait list here. We did the MRI a couple of days ago. He had severe night sweats, frequent urination etc and at the time of the initial examination enlarged prostate however the specialist said it was normal when he did the examination. Obviously this is a very stressful time and the wait for answers is very difficult to cope with for all of us. So how do I best support him through this process? It's so hard to see your partner going through this
Posts.Title: Hi Advice please

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Thank you Webster. Keep your spirits & hopes up that he may very well have been cured despite the advanced cancer. If it truly is a T3, that just means that it hit the seminal vesicles and went no further. Even in this type of case, if all of it was removed by the surgery, it should be gone forever. Can you tell us if the G7 was a 3+4 or a 4+3? Thanks Highlander, not sure he didn't say we were just processing the info at the time originally it was a 3 + 4 but that was before the prostate was graded when taken out. It def hit the seminal vesicle, had significant perennial (SP?) invasion but no lymph nodes which is a good sign. It's all good, we are taking one day at a time. OH has the catheter out tomorrow so he won't know himself. He's prepared for the issues of continence and of course the erectile dysfunction with both nerves being removed. It could be worse so grateful for that
